metadata.title: Leveling up AI-literacy for PMs. …and why I’m teaching Data Science for… | by Helen Mou | Towards Data Science
metadata.description: Today more than ever, data is at the core of product management. Product managers are increasingly responsible for shipping machine learning-driven product features, making critical product decisions…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: beer that is brewed by AI
University of San Francisco’s Data Institute

all_paragraphs: Today more than ever, data is at the core of product management. Product managers are increasingly responsible for shipping machine learning-driven product features, making critical product decisions based on machine learning techniques, and developing strong partnerships with their data science counterparts.
But when I asked data scientists and machine learning engineers about how their PM counterparts are doing, here is what I heard:
“My PM [doesn’t] know what questions to ask.”
The PM is “unable to frame what they are trying to solve as an ML problem.”
“PMs and executives are overconfident in their understanding, and overconfident in what is possible/easy.”
“Admit when you don’t understand something. Don’t pretend you know more than you do. Don’t make promises to the business without talking to the engineers.”

Too many organizations are hiring teams of data scientists without simultaneously investing in the data and AI-literacy of everyone else. As a result, there are too many product managers out there who are driving data scientists crazy (and vice versa, too).
Here’s why product managers need to become AI-literate:
❄️ 7 billion special snowflakes: Your users demand it. ️️❄️

The cat’s out of the bag — every individual wants to feel like (wait for it…) an individual. You, me, and all of our users demand intelligent, personalized experiences that make us feel like the special snowflakes that we are. If everyone else is getting the same thing as me, what’s so exciting about that?

When users give data to companies by registering an account, engaging with the application, and providing feedback, they expect the product to continuously improve and become more intelligent over time. These improvements often require productizing the data generated by the user’s engagement with the product itself.

AI-enabled products are all around us. Spotify uses your listening history to create personalized playlists, Gmail uses previous email content to finish your sentences, Woebot remembers past conversations in order to give you a personal therapy session, and IntelligentX’s AI algorithm uses your feedback from the previous batch of beer to create a recipe tailored just for your tastebuds. Yes, that’s right, you can now purchase beer that is brewed by AI.

Even if it’s just marketing hype, the fact that we are surrounded by all of these exciting developments is the very thing that endlessly increases our expectations and our “needs” (or wants). But for product managers, it’s not just hype — it’s your job to deliver on these expectations.
🥣 The Goldilocks PM: Not too technical, not too much hype 🥣

The job of a PM encompasses envisioning what future products are possible, and delivering what is valuable. In order to do this, PMs need to have a just-right amount of knowledge about the current state of data science technologies. This Goldilocks-level understanding enables PMs to bridge the gaps between teams of different expertise — business, technology, and design — without getting too caught up in the AI hype, or too deep into the weeds.

As a whole, the PM discipline is already well-versed in traditional software development technologies. This skillset is table stakes, across the board. When it comes to data science technologies, though, most PMs don’t have the same level of technical understanding as they already have in business, engineering, and design — and that’s because they haven’t always needed it.

Until now. As products become increasingly “intelligent” in order to meet the needs of each and every one of those special snowflake users out there, more and more of the application’s decision points will be taken over by predictive models, rather than by heuristics and explicit if-then-else logic.

Too often, PMs will drive their data science counterparts crazy by either getting too far into the technical weeds (less likely) or getting over-enthusiastic about hyped-up applications (more likely). The sweet spot is somewhere in between. A successful PM needs to understand the basics of data modeling, data infrastructure, machine learning models, and model evaluation metrics. Armed with just the right amount of knowledge, PMs can not only ship products that delight current users, but also deliver a vision of what is possible to create in the future.
🔮“ML isn’t magic”: Product managers need to understand the ML development process in order to effectively collaborate with the data science team*. 🔮

In order to build better partnerships (and products) with their data scientist and machine learning engineer counterparts, PMs need to understand major differences in the development process and where he or she can play the most impactful role.

Specifically, PMs can have the most impact in two areas: the model inputs and the model output. The “output” is the prediction that the ML model will generate. It’s critical that the PM clearly articulates the business value of this algorithm output, as well as the relevant constraints — great model predictions do not guarantee successful business results. The “inputs” are the features (aka attributes, independent variables, columns, etc.) that feed into the model. Garbage in, garbage out. Sharing domain knowledge and context with the data science team can help the team find stronger signal, leading to a higher-quality, more interpretable output.

As for the rest — step away and leave it to the black box of machine learning, right? Not so fast. As one data scientist said, “PMs need to know that ML isn’t magic.” Beyond the inputs and the outputs, there are many places in the development process where PMs can get tripped up unexpectedly. Here are some potential scenarios:

Bias, data cleaning, model evaluation…suffice to say, the development process for machine learning products is full of pitfalls that can easily derail a carefully planned product roadmap. AI-literate PMs can more easily foresee and proactively address these potential scenarios — before they happen.

To address these challenges, Professor Nick Ross and I developed a 7-week certificate course at the University of San Francisco’s Data Institute called Data Science for Product Managers. The certificate covers key data science and machine learning concepts, including analytics, statistics, regression, clustering, classification, NLP, recommendation systems, and deep learning — with a focus on product applications and business challenges.

By strengthening the AI literacy of PMs, we can build more effective partnerships between data scientists and product managers, and ship more intelligent products for all of the 7 billion special snowflakes out there.

* I am using “Data Science team” as an umbrella term to refer to the people who are building the product. This person’s title could be Machine Learning Engineer or Data Science Engineer (ideally), but is sometimes called simply “Data Scientist”. Most companies are still figuring out the best way to structure and title their data science teams.
⭐️ Thank you to my wonderful reviewers: Amelio Vazquez-Reina, Priya Mathew, Vincent Chio, Kona Shen, and Noah Fisher
